package.name: closure-html
package.documentation-string:
This package exports functions for HTML parsing and serialization. In addition, two simple in-memory data structures are included: LHTML, a lisp-list model. And PT, a simple structure instance model used by Closure internally.

function-definition.name: make-lhtml-builder
function-definition.documentation-string:
The lhtml-builder, a HAX handler. Create a HAX handler which builds LHTML list structures. Example: (chtml:parse "

nada

" (chtml:make-lhtml-builder)) => (:HTML NIL (:HEAD NIL) (:BODY NIL (:P NIL "nada"))) parse serialize-lhtml

function-definition.name: pt-name
function-definition.documentation-string: a pt node a keyword symbol Returns the element's name. HTML element names are symbols in the keyword package with uppercase names.

function-definition.name: parse
function-definition.documentation-string:
a pathname, stream, string, or octet array nil, or a HAX/SAX handler The return value of this function is determined by the handler argument; see below. Parse the HTML document given as an argument, or referred to using a pathname. input can have one of the following types:
pathname -- a Common Lisp pathname. Opens the file specified by the pathname parses it as an HTML document.
stream -- a Common Lisp stream that has already been opened.
array -- an (unsigned-byte 8) array. The array is parsed directly, and interpreted according to the encoding it specifies.
string/rod -- a rod (or string on unicode-capable implementations). Parses an XML document from the input string that has already undergone external-format decoding. If handler is nil, the parser's internal representation of the document is returned. The result is equivalent to that returned using a PT builder as returned by make-pt-builder, but avoids creating the same representation twice. Alternatively, handler can be a HAX handler (see hax:abstract-handler) or a SAX handler (see the SAX protocol in cxml). In this case, the document will be serialized to the specified handler, and the result of hax:end-document will be returned from this function. Note that the parser will currently always process the entire document before sending the first HAX event.

class-definition.name: pt
class-definition.documentation-string: Represents an HTML element. PT represents each HTML element as a structure instance, named by a keyword symbol. The children of a PT node are strings (rods) for text nodes, or other PT nodes for elements. make-pt-builder serialize-pt pt-name pt-children pt-parent pt-attrs

macro-definition.name: with-element
macro-definition.documentation-string: the element's name, a string/rod an implicit progn the value of body Generate hax:start-element and hax:end-element events. Execute body as an implicit progn. Send a start-element event to the current sink (before the first child element begins, or the current element ends), including all attributes specified using attribute until that point. Send an end-element event after body is finished. To be used in the extent of an with-html-output invocation.

function-definition.name: make-string-sink
function-definition.documentation-string: a HAX handler Returns a sink creating strings. This function creates a serialization sink. Sinks are HAX handlers that write events in their normal HTML syntax, and return the result from hax:end-document, if applicable. This particular kind of sink creates an HTML document in a string. The string is not encoded into an external-format. When writing this string to a Lisp character stream at a later point, make sure that the stream's external format agrees with the encoding declared by the document, if any. Supported only on Lisps with Unicode support. On Lisps without Unicode characters, try make-string-sink/utf8 as an alternative that has different encoding behaviour, but still uses strings. Or use make-rod-sink, which creates arrays of code points. make-character-stream-sink make-octet-stream-sink make-octet-vector-sink make-rod-sink

variable-definition.documentation-string: fixme: exported only for the benefit of Closure

function-definition.name: comment
function-definition.documentation-string: a string/rod the data Write a comment node. To be used in the extent of an with-html-output invocation, this function serializes a comment.

function-definition.name: pt-children
function-definition.documentation-string: a pt node a list Returns the element's children. The children of a PT node are strings (rods) for text nodes, or other PT nodes for elements. pt-parent

function-definition.name: text
function-definition.documentation-string: a string/rod the data Write a text node. To be used in the extent of an with-html-output invocation, this function serializes a text node.

function-definition.name: serialize-pt
function-definition.documentation-string:
an pt instance a HAX/SAX handler root element name, a rod/string nil or the Public ID, a rod/string nil or the System ID/URI, a rod/string The return value of this function is determined by the handler argument; see below. Serialize the PT node into HAX events, sent to the specified HAX handler. handler can be a HAX handler (see hax:abstract-handler) or a SAX handler (see the SAX protocol in cxml). The result of calling hax:end-document on the handler will be returned from this function. If system-id is specified, a doctype will be written according to the arguments name, public-id, and system-id. Use this function with a serialization sink to get a string or file with a serialized HTML document, or with a HAX/SAX builder to convert PT into a different representation, like DOM, LHTML, or STP. Example: (let ((x (chtml:parse "

nada

" (chtml:make-pt-builder))))) (chtml:serialize-pt x (chtml:make-string-sink)) => "

nada

" parse make-pt-builder

class-definition.name: pt-builder
class-definition.documentation-string: A HAX handler which builds PT structures. PT represents each HTML element as a structure instance of type pt. make-pt-builder serialize-pt

class-definition.name: lhtml-builder
class-definition.documentation-string: A HAX handler which builds LHTML list structures. LHTML represents each HTML element as a list of the form (name (attributes...) children...) and each attribute as a list of the form (name value) Element and attribute names are symbols in the keyword package with uppercase names. Attribute values are rods or strings. make-lhtml-builder serialize-lhtml

macro-definition.name: with-html-output
macro-definition.documentation-string: a HAX/SAX handler root element name, a rod/string nil or the Public ID, a rod/string nil or the System ID/URI, a rod/string an implicit progn the value of body Generate hax:start-document and hax:end-document events. Send a start-document event to the current sink, then execute body as an implicit progn. Afterwards, send an end-element event. with-output-sink with-element attribute text comment

function-definition.name: make-octet-stream-sink
function-definition.documentation-string: a HAX handler Returns a sink writing to an octet stream. This function creates a serialization sink. Sinks are HAX handlers that write events in their normal HTML syntax. This particular kind of sink writen the HTML document to a stream of element-type (unsigned-byte 8). make-character-stream-sink make-octet-vector-sink make-rod-sink make-string-sink

function-definition.name: make-rod-sink
function-definition.documentation-string: a HAX handler Returns a sink creating rods. This function creates a serialization sink. Sinks are HAX handlers that write events in their normal HTML syntax, and return the result from hax:end-document, if applicable. This particular kind of sink creates an HTML document in a rod. On Lisps with Unicode support, make-string-sink is an alias for this function. make-character-stream-sink make-octet-stream-sink make-octet-vector-sink make-string-sink

function-definition.name: make-octet-vector-sink
function-definition.documentation-string: a HAX handler Returns a sink creating octet vectors. This function creates a serialization sink. Sinks are HAX handlers that write events in their normal HTML syntax, and return the result from hax:end-document, if applicable. This particular kind of sink creates an HTML document in an array of (unsigned-byte 8). make-character-stream-sink make-octet-stream-sink make-rod-sink make-string-sink

function-definition.name: make-character-stream-sink
function-definition.documentation-string: a HAX handler Returns a sink writing to a character stream. This function creates a serialization sink. Sinks are HAX handlers that write events in their normal HTML syntax. This particular kind of sink writen the HTML document to a stream of element-type character. The characters written are not encoded into an external-format. Make sure that the stream's external format agrees with the encoding declared by the document, if any. Supported only on Lisps with Unicode support. On Lisps without Unicode characters, try make-character-stream-sink/utf8 as an alternative that has different encoding behaviour, but still uses character streams. make-octet-stream-sink make-octet-vector-sink make-rod-sink make-string-sink

function-definition.name: attribute
function-definition.documentation-string: a string/rod a string/rod or other object the value Add an attribute to the current element. To be used in the extent of an with-element invocation, this function adds an attribute to the element being serialized.

function-definition.name: serialize-lhtml
function-definition.documentation-string:
an LHTML list a HAX/SAX handler root element name, a rod/string nil or the Public ID, a rod/string nil or the System ID/URI, a rod/string The return value of this function is determined by the handler argument; see below. Serialize the LHTML document into HAX events, sent to the specified HAX handler. handler can be a HAX handler (see hax:abstract-handler) or a SAX handler (see the SAX protocol in cxml). The result of calling hax:end-document on the handler will be returned from this function. If system-id is specified, a doctype will be written according to the arguments name, public-id, and system-id. Use this function with a serialization sink to get a string or file with a serialized HTML document, or with a HAX/SAX builder to convert LHTML into a different representation, like DOM, PT, or STP. Example: (let ((x '(:HTML NIL (:HEAD NIL) (:BODY NIL (:P NIL "nada")))))) (chtml:serialize-lhtml x (chtml:make-string-sink)) => "

nada

" parse make-lhtml-builder

The pt-builder, a HAX handler. Create a HAX handler which builds pt structures. Example: (chtml:parse "

function-definition.name: pt-parent
function-definition.documentation-string: a pt node nil, or a pt node Returns the element's parent node. This slot should refer to the node's parent, if it is included in the list of that node's children. pt-children

function-definition.name: pt-attrs
function-definition.documentation-string: a pt node a plist Returns the element's attributes as a plist. This plist maps attribute names to their values. Attribute names are symbols in the keyword package with uppercase names. Attribute values are strings/rods.

macro-definition.name: with-output-sink
macro-definition.documentation-string: the variable name, a symbol an implicit progn the value of body Bind a variable to the current serialization sink. Execute body as an implicit progn with var bound to a serialization sink that body can safely call HAX functions on. To be used in the extent of an with-html-output invocation.

package.name: hax
package.documentation-string:
An event protocol for HTML serialization, this package is similar to the SAX protocol defined by cxml for XML serialization. (Technically, this package should have been spelled SAH, but HAX sounds better.) Note that Closure HTML is not a streaming parser yet. Documents are always parsed in full before the first HAX event is emitted. In spite of this restriction, the HAX API is useful for HTML serialization and transformation purposes, and for integration with SAX.
abstract-handler default-handler
standard-attribute make-attribute attribute-name attribute-value attribute-specified-p
start-document start-element end-element characters unescaped comment end-document

function-definition.name: characters
function-definition.documentation-string: a HAX/SAX handler (see abstract-handler for details) rod/string unspecified Signals character data. This event represents character data in a document. start-document start-element end-element comment end-document

function-definition.name: end-element
function-definition.documentation-string: a HAX/SAX handler (see abstract-handler for details) root element name, a rod/string unspecified Signals the end of an HTML element. This event corresponds to the closing tag of an element. start-document start-element characters unescaped comment end-document

function-definition.name: unescaped
function-definition.documentation-string: a HAX/SAX handler (see abstract-handler for details) rod/string unspecified Escaping bypass. This event writes raw characters into a document. Beware dragons. start-document start-element end-element comment end-document

function-definition.name: end-document
function-definition.documentation-string: a HAX/SAX handler (see abstract-handler for details) The return value of this function depends on the handler class. Signals the end of an HTML document. This is the last event sent to any handler, and signals the end of serialization. The return value of this function is usually returned to user code by higher-level serialization functions and can be considered the result of serialization and "return value" of the handler. start-document start-element end-element characters unescaped comment

class-definition.name: default-handler
class-definition.documentation-string: A no-op HAX handler. This class defines methods for all HAX events that do nothing. It is useful as a superclass when implementing a HAX handler that is interested in only some events and not others. chtml:parse chtml:serialize-lhtml chtml:serialize-pt start-document end-document start-element end-element characters unescaped comment

function-definition.name: comment
function-definition.documentation-string: a HAX/SAX handler (see abstract-handler for details) rod/string unspecified Signals a comment. This event represents a comment. start-document start-element end-element characters unescaped end-document

function-definition.name: attribute-specified-p
function-definition.documentation-string: any class implementing this function a string/rod Return whether the attribute was contained the parsed document. Attributes return nil here if they resulted from a default value declaration in a DTD. Instances of this classes implementing this function can be passed to hax:start-element in the list of attributes. attribute-name attribute-value

class-definition.name: standard-attribute
class-definition.documentation-string: An implementation of the HAX attribute protocol. A standard class implementing the generic functions for HAX attributes. Instances of this class can be passed to hax:start-element in the list of attributes. attribute-name attribute-value attribute-specified-p make-instance

function-definition.name: find-attribute
function-definition.documentation-string: a string/rod a list of attributes an attribute, or nil Searches for an attribute by name. Returns the first attribute in attrs with the specified name, or nil if no such attribute was found. attribute-name

function-definition.name: start-document
function-definition.documentation-string: a HAX/SAX handler (see abstract-handler for details) root element name, a rod/string nil or the Public ID, a rod/string nil or the System ID/URI, a rod/string unspecified Signals the beginning of an HTML document. This is the first event sent to any handler. If system-id is non-nil, the document includes a doctype declaration. start-element end-element characters unescaped comment end-document

function-definition.name: attribute-name
function-definition.documentation-string: any class implementing this function a string/rod Return an attribute's name. Instances of this classes implementing this function can be passed to hax:start-element in the list of attributes. attribute-value attribute-specified-p

function-definition.name: start-element
function-definition.documentation-string: a HAX/SAX handler (see abstract-handler for details) root element name, a rod/string a list of attributes unspecified Signals the beginning of an HTML element. This event corresponds to the opening tag of an element. Elements of the attribute list can have any class, but must implement the generic functions for attributes. See standard-attribute for the built-in attribute implementation. find-attribute start-document end-element characters unescaped comment end-document

function-definition.name: attribute-value
function-definition.documentation-string: any class implementing this function a string/rod Return an attribute's value. Instances of this classes implementing this function can be passed to hax:start-element in the list of attributes. attribute-name attribute-specified-p

function-definition.name: make-attribute
function-definition.documentation-string: a string/rod a string/rod a boolean, default is t an instance of standard-attribute. Creates a HAX attribute. Creates an instance that can be used with the generic functions for HAX attributes. The result can be passed to hax:start-element in the list of attributes. attribute-name attribute-value attribute-specified-p

class-definition.name: abstract-handler
class-definition.documentation-string: The superclass of all HAX handlers. Direct subclasses have to implement all event methods, since no default methods are defined on this class. Note that it is permissible to use handlers that are not instances of this class in some circumstances. In particular, nil is a valid HAX handler and ignores all events. In addition, SAX handlers are valid HAX handlers (and vice versa), even though hax:abstract-handler and sax:abstract-handler do not share a specific superclass. HAX events sent to SAX handlers are automatically re-signalled as XHTML SAX events, and SAX events sent to HAX handlers are re-signalled as namespace-less HAX events. However, user code should define subclasses of the documented superclasses to enable the HAX/SAX bridging described above. chtml:parse chtml:serialize-lhtml chtml:serialize-pt start-document end-document start-element end-element characters unescaped comment
